intro: Adenostemma lavenia var. longifolium, commonly known as the long-leaved adenostemma, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, two-lipped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in open woodlands or along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in certain regions.
